1. KALASHA INDIGENOUS TRIBE OF PAKISTAN

2. Group Members Ammar Khalid Muhammad Sohaib Junaid Ijaz Najeeb Khan Sheraz Ahmad Ali Afzal Fazal Hussain

4. Introduction • The Kalasha (Urdu: ‫کاالش‬ ,) or Kalash, also called Black Kafir. • A Dardic Indo-Aryan indigenous people residing in the Chitral District of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa province of Pakistan. • They are also considered to be Pakistan's smallest ethnoreligious group.

5. Location • Kalash are people who lives in the Chitral District of Khyber Pakhtunkhua. • Kalash people are mostly found in valleys of “Rumbur”, “Bumburet” and “Birir”.

6. Origin of Kalash There are three theories about the origin of Kalash: Kalash are descendants of Alexander The Great. Kalash are indigenous to Asia and come from what is now the Nuristan area of Afghanistan in 2nd century BC.

7. Origin of Kalash • Kalasha people believe that their ancestors migrated to Afghanistan from a distant place in South Asia, which the kalash call “Tsiyam” in their Folk songs and epics. • Some people say that “Tsiam” is the ancient name of Thailand.

8. History • Black Kafirs • Ruled by Mehtar of Chitral from 18th century onward. • Invaded by British in 1890s. • 1970 Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto took initiative to conserve it.

9. Nature in the Valley • Kalash valley is lush green with chilled water streams. • Valley is full of apple and apricot trees, but their main crop is maze, women harvest the maze crop with local songs.

10. Religion • The Kalash peoples believe in a single, creative God, referred to in the Kalasha language as ‘Dezau’. • Nature plays a highly spiritual role in their daily life. • Kalasha people do have different names of temples such as Sajigor, Indrain and Warin etc. • It is a place to offer sacrifice to Dezau.

11. Language • Kalasha is an Indo-European language in the Indo-Aryan branch spoken by Kalash people. • There are estimated 6000 speakers of Kalasha. • They speak fusion of Dardiac and Sanskrit.

12. Traditional Dresses • Kalash people have a unique and colorful dress that serves as the most obvious symbol of identity for the Kalash community, • Their women usually wear long black robes, often embroidered with cowrie shells. • They also wear beautiful head dress made from shells, buttons and twinkling bells.

13. Traditional Dresses • Kalasha men normally wear Shalwar- Kameez, which is combination trousers. • They wear caps called as ‘Chitrali’ generally of black or white color .

14. Festivals

15. Festivals UTCHAL:  Utchal happens to be a two day celebrations that makes the harvest season of wheat and barley.  On this event, a lot of dancing and singing is witnessed.  This feast is called “kil’a’a saras”.

16. Festivals JOSHI FESTIVAL:  Joshi festival is celebrated on 14th and 15th May and it marks the beginning of spring.  During this festival flowers are plucked.  Dance sessions are held and exchange of dairy products take place.  First flower of the year plucked is a yellow species widely popular as bechu.

18. Festivals CHOWMAS:  Chowmas is the festival that is celebrated between 18th to 21st December.  It marks the New Year happiness and the first season of snow fall.  This festival last for a week.  Sacrifices, feast and celebration take place with light torches and dance performances.

19. Festivals UCHAO:  It is celebrated in mid of August.  Newly made cheese is brought from the pastures.  Ceremony is held at the alter of Mahandeo.  Dancing and singing take place until dawn.

21. Customs

22. Customs • Childhood to Manhood: • Even if a boy is born, he is not considered as ‘man’ until he is six years old. • The boy has to live with women and he is not allowed to wear pants or pyjamas for six years since his birth. • A big celebration is held when a boy turns six and wears a ‘shalwar’ or pants. After that he eats only with men and not with women. • A goat is also sacrificed to mark the occasion and the meat is eaten only by the men.

23. • Bashali: • Wooden hut in each village. • Women sent to live their during menstruation period. • Exempted from house chores. • No man can come near them. • Childbirth Customs

24. Customs • Divorce: • Kalasha girls are free to choose their life partners and also have the right to divorce. • Wife-elopement is one of the great customs (ghōna dastūr) together with the main festivals. • Second husband has to pay double.

25. Sacrifice: • A goat is also sacrificed to mark the occasion and the meat is eaten only by the men. • Sick person. • New House. Property: • Distributed among sons. • Daughters are given life stocks and gifts. Customs

26. • Prayer: • Head Covering. • Bathing. • Fire is made and blood is poured on it. • Goat is sacrificed and elders pray. • Mourning is considered impure and celebration is holy. Customs

28. GURU • A historic place in Birir valley, is famous for its ancient and multi-tiered abodes, cultural sites and a dancing hall.

29. Kalash Culture Centre • The Kalash Culture Centre is in Brun, Bumburet valley, where folk history, culture and civilization of the Kalash is preserved under one roof.

30. Jeshtak-Han • This is a large hall. • Decorated with female paintings and animal figures. • Jeshtak-Han is holy place where rituals are performed at the times of birth, death and festivals.

31. Charsu • A dancing place where young couples gather to perform a dance in commemoration of their love.

32. Occupation • People are moving towards a cash-based economy whereas previously wealth was measured in livestock and crops. • Tourism now makes up a large portion of the economic activities of the kalash. • People attempting to enter the valley have to pay toll to Pakistani government which to preserve Kalash people. • Honey is collected from traditional bee hives is an important source of income for dweller of Kalash valley.

33. Food • Mantus, a Central Asian dish of steamed beef dumplings popular in area due to influences from Badakhshan. • Pilaf usually of beef which is pre-boiled and the meat is served lying on top of the rice.

34. • Salty buttered tea, green tea and very bitter black tea, called Troq Chai, are all very popular as well. • Honey, cheese and fresh fruits also make up a staple part of the Chitrali diet as these products. Food

35. Marriages • There are no restrictions for love or arrange marriages. • If a woman asked for a girl for her son she would put a necklace around girls neck. • When bring bride at home man offers sacrifice. • Blood of animal is sprinkled on floor.

36. Funeral Rituals • These are one of the interesting traditions. • All of the relative and non- relatives are invited on the funeral. • Dead body is not buried and funeral is set on for 3 days or so. • Till then all feeding expense is taken by dead’s family. • All the things in use of dead are buried with dead.

37. • Death is a celebration in kalash culture. • A song called ‘kaana’ is sung that tells how dead first came and all the great things done by them. Funeral Rituals

38. Graveyards • Originally Kalash people leave their dead on a wooden coffin exposed to the weather and let it rot. • A wooden statue is placed near the coffin in a ceremony to project the bravery of the dead man. • Often animals ate the dead bodies ang things with dead were stolen. • Later on they started putting dead in coffin and bury them.

39. • This is the ancient graveyard in Bumberet valley. Graveyards

40. Endangered Kalash Culture • The Kalash are one of the world endangered minority community. • Their population decreased from 8000 in 1951 to 4000 in 2006. • Kalash places of worship, graveyards and other cultural monuments are also considered as threatened. • Many features and monuments of kalash are on decline because of forceful conversion of community by neighboring Muslims.

41. Current Management System. • At present the Kalash protection and conservation matters are being managed by District Government of Chitral. • The District has support of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa with technical assistance from UNESCO. • Management practices include arrangements for cultural festivals, tourist information and facilitation system.

42. Conclusion • We can see color of nature fallen on earth in kalash valley. • With their unique language and customs it has its own significance. • Deserves to be conserve before it get extinct.
